problem.tex: Let $X$ be a compact Riemann surface. Prove that if there is a meromorphic function on $X$ having exactly one pole, and that pole has order one, then $X$ is equivalent to the Riemann sphere.

solution.tex: Let $f:X\to S^2$ be the given meromorphic function. Since $f$ has only a single pole of order one, we know that the cardinality $|f^{-1}(\infty)| = 1$, and by the degree theorem (degree is constant), $deg(f) = 1$. Therefore for any point $y \in S^2$ there is exactly one point $x \in f^{-1}(y)$. Hence $f$ is a bijective map. Note that $f^{-1}$ is also a continuous map since the image under $f$ of a closed set in $X$ is compact in $S^2$ and hence closed. This implies $f$ is a homeomorphism. By a corollary of the inverse function theorem, this implies $f^{-1}$ is also holomorphic. Hence $X$ is equivalent to $S^2$, by the biholomorphism $f$.
